'Carl Oskar Ursinus' (March 11, 1877 – July 6, 1952) was a pioneer of
German aviation and is remembered mainly for his contributions to sailplane
designs and the sport of gliding. He has been nicknamed the RhÃ¶nvater ("RhÃ¶n
father") because he founded Germanyâs first gliding club at the Wasserkuppe in
the RhÃ¶n Mountains in 1920.

Ursinus was born in WeiÃenfels and attended Technical College in Mittweida.
After graduation, he worked for Borsig on compressors for locomotives and spent
some time working on mining machinery in Romania for the firm.

In 1908, back in Germany, Ursinus began to publish a magazine titled
Flugsport (âSports Flyingâ), since he had become fascinated by the new
technology of flight. The magazine helped establish a network amongst
Germanyâs aviation enthusiasts and led to the organisation of Germanyâs first
international airshow.

He was conscripted into the German Army in 1914 and requested a position in
aircraft design. The request was approved and he was posted to Gothaer
Waggonfabrik designing warplanes. The famous series of Gotha bombers used by the
German air corps throughout World War I were all based on an Ursinus design of
1915 that was refined and manufactured as the Gotha G.I. Ursinus' real passion,
however, was for seaplanes, and in 1916 he designed a revolutionary seaplane
fighter with retractable floats that was unfortunately destroyed before testing
was complete.

Following the war, the Treaty of Versailles prohibited Germany from building
powered aircraft, and the attention of German aviators therefore turned to
gliding. A plateau particularly suited to gliding, the Wasserkuppe, became a
focal point for this activity, and in 1920, Ursinus organised a competition
there. Twenty-four people attended the meeting between 15 July and 15 September
1920 including Wolf Hirth and other gliding pioneers. (see also RhÃ¶n-Rossitten
Gesellschaft.)

Over the next decade, this grew in importance to become an international event.
Ursinus also constructed the first clubhouse on the Wasserkuppe in 1924. He was
pursuing experiments in human-powered flight when the outbreak of World War II
intervened.

Following the war, powered flying was once again forbidden in Germany, but
Ursinus lived just long enough to see this prohibition lifted.

Today, he is regarded in Germany as the father of gliding, and Germanyâs
association for homebuilt aircraft, the [[Oskar Ursinus-Vereinigung]] ("Oskar
Ursinus Association") bears his name.
